summary: Sun Tzu teaches that intelligence defines the outcome of war. Five types of spies—local, inward, converted, doomed, and surviving—each serve strategic purposes. Accurate information allows generals to win without waste.
content:
Sun Tzu said: To remain ignorant of enemy conditions while relying on luck is the height of cruelty.

No one should be trusted more than the spy. Information determines victory. Without intelligence, a general is blind.

There are five types of spies: local, inward, converted, doomed, and surviving. Each gathers different information and serves unique purposes.

Spies must be paid well and treated with dignity. Only trustworthy spies produce trustworthy intelligence.

When all five types are in use, no secret remains hidden. Such is the power of foreknowledge.

micro_lessons.question: Why does Sun Tzu consider relying on luck cruel?
micro_lessons.answer: Because ignorance leads to needless casualties.
